awd_titl_txt: REU Site:   Research Experiences for Undergraduates in Atomic, Molecular, and Biological Physics
awd_abstract_narration:
The Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) site at the Molecular Physics Laboratory at SRI International provides six undergraduate students each summer the opportunity to participate in research on topics in atomic, molecular and biological physics. This program offers talented undergraduates the opportunity to perform summer research in a non-university research laboratory. This program produces students who understand the process of performing research, starting with the development of the problem and continuing with evaluation of the approach, performing measurements, and drawing conclusions. This training helps prepare the Nation's future well-trained workforce required to continue to lead an increasingly technological world.

In addition to participating in research with an experienced mentor, the REU students will engage in weekly activities such as seminars, ethics training, safety training, and visits to other research laboratories, to ensure not only that their research stays on track but that they have an engaging collegial and scholarly experience. By the end of the program, every student will have presented the results of the work in a thirty-minute seminar. The host laboratories, known for research in physics and interdisciplinary offshoots of physics based research, have a proven record of undergraduate research as evidenced by the number of student coauthors in journal publications.

Project Outcomes Report

Over three consecutive summers (2017-2019), the REU Site: Research Experiences for Undergraduates in Atomic, Molecular, and Biological Physics at SRI International has provided undergraduate students from all over the country a unique opportunity to pursue research in a non-academic setting at one of Silicon Valley's premier non-profit research institutions. The 21 participants in our program were selected from a pool of over 240 talented applicants. Special emphasis was placed on recruiting diverse groups each summer, with 57% of our participants in the past 3 years being women and 19% of the students being under-represented minorities. The students contributed significantly to advancing a variety of research areas including the development of microscale droplet methods, methods for rapid polymerase chain reaction (PCR) for amplification of DNA, application of mass spectrometry to biological analyses, radar-based studies of the ionosphere, development of hyperspectral imaging methods, study of new molecular recognition ligands, and high-throughput single cell analysis.

Each REU student in our program was mentored by a staff scientist in our laboratory and in-depth training was often supplemented with postdoctoral fellows in the laboratory. Most students had more than one advisor. A total of 15 Ph.D. staff members or postdocs advised the students, providing a range of scientific viewpoints. Environmental safety personnel and ergonomics specialists were available on campus to train the students in lab safety protocols and good work practices. The students performed research on a small project that was part of a larger research program with the assigned mentor(s). The students received extensive hands-on training in various aspects of performing research in a laboratory setting, from conceptualizing the problem, to executing experiments, analyzing data, and, finally, presenting their work to the scientists and their peers at a seminar series at the end of the summer. The students also benefitted from several seminars over the summer, given by scientists at SRI International and invited guest speakers from a variety of institutions. To complement these scientific interactions, the program included visits to industrial, university, and government laboratories in Silicon Valley. Some examples of such activities over the past three summers include visits to the Stanford Linear Accelerator Center; the NASA Ames Research Center; the laboratories of Nobel Laureate W.E. Moerner at Stanford; the laboratories of Robert L. Byer and Martin M. Fejer at Stanford; and two start-up companies in Silicon Valley: Grabit  - a company developing electroadhesion tools to automate the handling of virtually any material, and LeoLabs - a company mapping objects using phase array radars to secure safe and sustainable operations in low earth orbit.

Summer research programs for undergraduate students are also a vehicle for them to decide whether scientific research is a career path they would like to take after graduation. Scientists in our laboratory mentored students on wide ranging career-related topics that included one-on-one sessions with students about what to expect out of a Ph.D. program, lateral career choices in science and engineering after an undergraduate degree, and information on graduate schools. One measure of the success of our program lies in the fraction of our REU students that opt for graduate school. Approximately 70% of our student participants are currently involved in research. Our program has helped in developing a qualified STEM workforce by providing training and establishing a strong foundation for research and development in these undergraduates.
